title: Pens: What makes blue ink better for memorization as opposed to black ink? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don't see that as being essential one way or another in regard to the aid to memory. The text itself is the main thing and if well written it can aid memory. If not, then memory is hindered by such phrasing. I remember the problem from my School studies when I tried to rephrase what the text book said for the Physics homework. It led to no end of aggro. Cryptic this and cryptic that. That's basically what I got from the teachers remarks. My friend just copied the text in the text book and got no problems in doing so. The original text in the text book was obviously black. Maybe black ink is cheaper than blue ink and that's why it's used. :I liked blue ink as well as black ink for my pens yet switched to purple-black later on as that looked more distinctive to me at that time. Nowadays it's pick up a pen and write with it. But the days of fountain pens are basically behind me now. I would also question whether the pen itself has a better chance of us remembering text. I used italic pens till teachers began to dictate text to the class and quickly discarded that type of pen in favour of a biro. :Later on, I got even faster-flowing pens. That led to the ability to write more words in a limited time, such as for homework and exams. Another factor is using a fine point rather than a medium or broad tipped pen, whether a fountain pen or some other pen. Another factor is that web pages have guidelines and shorter lines are easier to read and to understand. It's the same with writing poetry for poetry publishers and competitions. Perhaps a maximum of 70 characters including spaces. So presentation matters as does the use of handwriting styles, or calligraphy styles, or basic text that separates each letter for easier reading displays.:Memory aids like highlighting text will prove useful, yet my teachers encouraged us to provide headings for our paragraphs to identify topics quickly. Even so, the aim was getting top marks and that led to writing more text. That meant trying to learn more text later on. So the more we read, the more we need. Whatever makes it easier to read gets my vote, but blue tends to fade, while black tends to be a dominant colour when using broad point pens. So I'd suggest a fine point black ink pen's text would be easier to read and to remember.:

response.answer_text: Black is the most common color we see (every shadow in every crevice and object) and is easy to ignore unless we pick up on some other clue that it’s something worth looking at. Blue tends to be relatively rare in nature and something that is worthy of attention. However, I seriously doubt that there’s a statistical correlation when someone habitually uses blue or black ink. You’d rapidly numb yourself to any attention getting effect or psychological advantage. Mixing up the colors and correlating them to subjects, note type or other patterns would likely be more impactful that just sticking to a blue or black pen. In many fields, the color of the ink was actually correlated to the seniority or authoritative nature of what was being written. Blue was the standard “worker bee” color, black was for managers and green was either an intern color or for senior managers (depending on the field/office). That way you could immediately tell how much authority a note had or the level of any signature. Offices tended to maintain large stores of blue pens and much smaller batches of black, green, red and light blue.

I am not sure of the other answers but they sound intuitively correct. I am going to say that if you study memory techniques, color is significant for bringing the right brain into the pattern. Most of what we are doing in learning is left brain (verbal skills including writing, naming, logic, sequential. Color is often urged in mind mapping and other note taking and it is used to have the memory connection of dendrites pass through the medulla oblongata where the two hemispheres of the brain are connected. There may be uncertainty as to why it is true but there is no doubt that it is a way to amplify transfer from short term to long term memory. It is inherently a major aspect of any effective memory technique whether conscious or not. But using blue ink instead of black ink is only one small piece. It is like making a cake with flour but no eggs, sugar, etc. Get a good book on memory, study and note-taking techniques. I recommend Tony Buzan. When you visualize and associate, use a lot of imagination and COLOR.

response.answer_text: In my opinion,  colour of the ink does not matter much for memorization of any written material.
